title: The Dawn of Man: 2001 A Space Odyssey Action Scene EvD

description.text: Relive the dramatic appearance of the mysterious monolith with The Dawn of Man: 2001 A Space Odyssey Action Scene. Comes complete with the first sentient ape, iconic spinning-in-midair water buffalo femur, and an exciting collection of lesser ape figurines. Place your iPhone in the Monolith holder and cue the 2001 theme song (best version ever is here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wpFQLw5_N2o and the real theatrical release is here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ML1OZCHixR0).

Print out all parts. Glue the "MonolithHolder" (iPhone base) and "ProjectileArc" pieces to "Bedrock." If necessary, clean the stem of the "BoneInSpace" then insert into the arc. Use a hot knife to flatten the base and lock it into position. Once assembled, contemplate the significance of the monolith with your fellow simians. Better yet, buy the feature film for your iPhone, make a bowl of popcorn, and watch it with your new mates. Bre Rising (seen in promotional picture) is a derivative of Thingiverse file: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9010 Inspiration also drawn from Monkey for a Container Full of Primates... http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3748. Special thanks to Arthur C. Clarke, Jerry Goldsmith, and Stanley Kubrick. We ran out of time and plastic for the "Bedrock" and put what we had on cardboard.

title: RC KTM Ascender
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Heavily inspired by some images from 2008 i came across on the net i have been wanting to 3D model and build this for many years. I've been working on this for nearly 2 years in odd moments when i have time

Update2 > uploaded the cosmetics ( tank, seat etc) All the new files have the number "2" as a prefix.
Ive also, alongside the original, added a 2 part version of the battery compartment for easier printing
Update1 > FC PDB base is now Rev1a = Original had FC board in stl Oops Good now

First test hops in the dining room,
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I9EW7ZZrlag

The main frames are printed from ABS to be durable but this definitely isn't something that will survive hard landings or crashes very well.
I have only provided left hand side parts so certain items need to be mirrored

The main frame prints flat on a 200 X 200 bed It then carefully needs to be heated and bent . Info on bending attached in drawing
Obviously had to adapt a few things to make it fly but the core layout is intact.
Most joints are either solvent or friction welded
Here's a link to friction welding hhhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Cj9TMmUldhc

I printed the main frames from ABS with 80% infil.
Once the main skeletal frame was built i adjusted for warping with a hot air gun

The outrigger struts ar 3mm OD solid carbon fiber rod and the rear yaw drive shaft it carbon tube 5 mm OD / 3mm ID

The equipment ive used can be found in the following links
These are affiliate links that cost you nothing but give me points towards my next project,
Much appreciatted if you choose to use the links.

FC =http://www.banggood.com/Afro-Naze32-10DOF-Rev5-MPU6050-Flight-controller-p-1007113.html?X9120314803172015043
Any 6 or 10 dof FC with a 30.5mm hole centre patern will fit ( FLip 32)
PDB = http://www.banggood.com/CC3D-NAZE32-F3-Power-Distribution-Board-PDB-With-Filter-BEC-Output-5V-12V-3A-for-QAV250-p-1023543.html?X9120314803172015043
Motor = http://www.banggood.com/Racerstar-Racing-Edition-2205-BR2205-2300KV-2-4S-Brushless-Motor-CWCCW-Black-For-QAV250-ZMR250-260-p-1086693.html?X9120314803172015043
&
ESC's = http://www.banggood.com/BL20A-OneShot-125-OPTO-2-4s-Mini-Brushless-20A-BLHeli-ESC-For-FPV-QAV180-250-p-1023318.html?X9120314803172015043
Props = http://www.banggood.com/2-Pairs-DAL-Pro-5045-3-Blade-CWCCW-Propeller-for-FPV-Racing-Muliticopter-p-1056430.html?X9120314803172015043
( I trimmed the props down to fit the ducts )
Servo is a Corona met gear servo https://hobbyking.com/en_us/corona-919mg-digital-metal-gear-servo-1-7kg-0-06sec-12g.html

RX = Frsky Dr4II http://www.banggood.com/FrSky-D4RII-24G-4CH-ACCST-Telemetry-Receiver-p-929069.html?X9120314803172015043

If you'd like one of these (3D printed parts), check out my 3D Hub.

A katana inspired lightsaber I made for a Halloween costume prop. The pieces twist lock together with a bit of friction, though you could glue them.
I used the guts from a toy lightsaber for lights and sounds: this one
For the blade, I just used a fluorescent light tube guard sanded down to make it light up better and lightly painted red (which you could skip as the LED from the toy is already red.
Its a pretty tight fit, and you'll have to solder a bit to get wires the right length for the speaker and such and come up with a solution for holding the 3 AAA batteries. I used this thing for the batteries. Also, I drilled a hole for the button and made a little standoff to activate the saber. Its worth the effort, though, because you end up with light and sound effects.
Enjoy!

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

20%

Assembly

The parts twist lock together. With the tolerances on my printer, they stay together with friction, though if a piece is loose, or becomes loose over time, you can use a bit masking tape on the male end to increase friction for a better hold. Just cut a few tiny squares and stick them on various spot of the "plug", adding more until it feels good to you. I did the same with the tube I used for my blade, so help it stay on when swinging.
For the belt clip ring, you have two options, you can print it first and then carefully put it into place as the hilt is printing, or just snip it near a corner and put it through after, using some strong glue to keep it together afterwards.

Painting

To get the aged saber effect, I primed with filler primer, sanded, and then spray painted the parts in their base metallic colors, gold and silver. Next, I took black, brown, and yellow (very little yellow) acrylic paint and just mashed an old brush into the colors to get a sort of random mix. Cover the whole saber (which should be assembled without the electronics) in this paint, remixing and smudging as you go. Once the whole thing is covered, and you will get messy doing this, let it dry for about 2 minutes and then take a rag and rub off as much as you can. Repeat until it looks as grimy as you like. I also darkened specific areas, such as the diamond shapes, but carefully putting the paint into those spots and letting them dry longer before wiping.
The saber was originally designed for a 1 inch outer diameter tube, but I couldn't get one, so instead I had to put the tube over the protrusion on the emitter. So, to make it look right while the blade was attached, I painted the end of the tube to look like the end of my emitter and carefully grunged it up to match. this also hid the tape used to keep things secure.
Designed in 123d Design

comments.text: It's actually just gold and "aluminum" spray paint.  First I coated it in Rustoleum filler primer, gave it a good sanding, more filler primer, then sprayed the various parts their colors.  Afterwards I used black, brown and yellow acrylic paints from Wal-mart to cover the whole thing in "dirt".  Let it set for about 30 seconds to a minute then wiped it off as best I could.  Repeated that a few times and there ya go.  I hadn't yet discovered rub n' buff when I made this, but I do kind of want to try it on one of these at some point.  Working on some new saber designs, so maybe on the next one?

title: Infinity Fractal Snowflake
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a 2D art/decoration piece that can be linearly extruded for 3D printing, but the intent is to create a design for a 2D snowflake for laser cutting a stencil, or out of acrylic to make an ornament for your tree or house.

It is derived from my thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1337341

This is a customizable object, so your can use the customizer to explore different parameters to make the snowflake you want. Customizer currently does not allow for download of the .svg file that needs to be exported so you will probably have to download OpenScad to get the .svg file that will allow you to cut the stencil or ornament.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Mini

No

No

Resolution:

Infill:

100

Notes:

We are using a Epilog 60W at the http://gjmakerspace.org/ to cut the stencils and house decorations.

Laser cutting

OpenScad can export to .svg and .svg files can be setup to be laser cut. Check out our instructables on how to take our infinity fractal and then laser cut or etch the result. Same process will work for these snowflakes. See http://www.instructables.com/id/Transfiguration-Bustle-Laser-Cutetched-Leaf

description.text: My first thing on Thingiverse. This is a simple mobius strip shaped bead. It should work nicely as an earring and fit any wire up to 18 gauge. It's about 1 3/8" across. I haven't printed it yet. Print yourself a pair and take a picture.

comments.text: I'm working on getting a good print of this in the orientation shown (vertical) and without support.  The main thing is that I added a small cylinder at the base, so that there is good contact with the build plate.  At 52% scale and a ~.09mm layer height my machine manages the top bridge with a minimum of stringing. (cylinder size = 12.5mm dia, 1.5mm height vs earrings at published scale)  The last requirement I realized was to enlarge the hole for the ear wire, when printing at 52%.  Hopefully I'll be publishing a remix soon, it depends whether the earrings are well-received or not.

remixed_from.author: 3DCentralVA
remixed_from.title: Articulated Jellyfish! Ball-joint articulated octopus Remix!

title: Jellyfish Mod Resized for ease of Assembly

description.text:
My first 3D printer arrived 2 weeks ago, the Flashforge New Creator Pro. After it arrived, we began looking through the files on Thingiverse and my oldest daughter couldn't wait to print out the Jellyfish. Our color selection was low, so that is why it is Black and Yellow.

The original model is very nice, and well put together. It was an excellent model to learn 3D printing with. The whole model was printed in Hatchbox PLA, on the FF New Creator Pro. The gcode was created using the ReplicatorG Sailfish software and PyPy. We really enjoyed making this model.

A BIG thanks to "CarryTheWhat" on the Top piece of the model, the art work for this piece alone is Awesome!

Also a BIG thanks to Ellindsey, for the original files uploaded for the Octopus, the ball-joint links are fun to play with!

If I knew more, perhaps I could have printed this out using the original scale of the files provided, but being a newbie, I had issues where the tentacles were frozen and would not rotate. To remedy I simply printed everything out 50% larger.

I also had issues with printing out the bottom base. For some reason the top and bottom surfaces of it would not print out... only a outer-ring of ball-sockets resulted... I'm betting this is due to the ReplicatorG Sailfish software, and not the model itself. Anyway to remedy I took the Skull-Head model uploaded by Ellindsey, and revised it in Google Sketchup; I cut the base free, selected one ball-socket and cleaned it up, and then copied it several time into a circle to make a new ball-socket ring. I then added new flat surfaces for the top and bottom. This model prints great.

Also I learned that snapping the tentacles into the base was near impossilble. As a Dad, I could do it, but it took all my strength, and some sand paper. I could hear the PLA cracking as I did so. ABS would probably be better as it is more flexible.

To remedy, the final design has the bottom piece slightly larger, at 155% of the original size. The Tentacles snap much better (no sand paper needed); effort still required though. Also the Tentacle end piece is smaller at only 145% of the original; allowing them to snap-in more easily to the end of the tentacle links. The files uploaded depict the percentages that I trialed and found to work for me. You can print out these files as is or experiment further on your own on the sizing.

Just another quick-side note:
I had difficulty getting the PLA parts to stick to the bed when printing them out. The blue surface that Flashforge provided with the printer was worthless. What worked for me was a piece of Dollar Store glass (cut to size), covered in green "frog-tape" from Walmart, I then rubbed a white plastic eraser all over the frog-tape's surface. The parts stuck like a champ, and were easy to remove later, hot or cold.

Edit: 2018-01-21

I no longer use blue tape and glue stick. Instead I use a clear sheet of PEI cut to size and glued down to the original bed. It becomes tacky as the bed heats up, and PLA and PETG sticky very well to it.

This is an update to my Christmas ornament I created for last year. I modified to make it work with the customizer. You can set the main text. If the main text is to large to fit, you can change the scale of the text. I wanted to allow the year text to be set as well, but I can't get customizer to work if the input parameter needs to be a string but have a number as it's value, like 2013. You can also somewhat customize the snowman family. You can select how many snowman to generate up to 5. And the gender of each snowman. The way it works is snowman 1 is the largest, snowman 2 is the second largest and so on. So you can make the biggest be a man, the second biggest be a woman, etc.
What I did was to customize the number of snowmen based on the actual number of people in each family I gave it to. Note: If you leave Enable Support on (the default) you will get little tabs supporting the year digits that you can easily break off. You will also get small support cones that help keep the sphere from detaching from the build plate while printing. Enable Support is misleading, set to "Yes" if you are NOT going to enable support in makerware. This is what I recommend as everything is designed to print without the generated support. Note2, if you download the scad, you can customize a lot more stuff, including dualstrusion. I didn't enable for customizer because this scad is already too slow to render, enabling dualstrusion would have make it have to render 3 times. It seems to take about 8 - 9 minutes to render currently. Update: I noticed the file I had uploaded did not respect the setting for number of snowmen. I have updated so that setting works now. Update 11/9/2014: updated date to 2014 Update 12/11/2015: Fixed issue with customizer. Fixed ability to customize year. Updated year to 2015. Update 12/9/2016: I noticed the the formatting of the summary was messed up, also somewhere I lost the references to the "things" this was based on.

comments.text: Customizer doesn't seem to work with text fields that only contain a number. That's why the year is hard coded. Can you download open scad from here: http://www.openscad.org then download the file "ornament_v2.2.scad" under thing files. Open that file with openscad, you should see the year and all of the other parameter fields in the first few lines. Then hit F6, or Compile and Render from the menu. Render is what generates the model. Then you just export as an STL file.
comments.author: doobe

comments.text: One thing I forgot to mention is the scad file uses wite.scad (www.thingiverse.com/thing:16193).  Customizer expects it to be in a sub directory.  So create a sub directory called "write" under where you have ornament_v2_2.scad and unzip the files from thing 16193 into that directory.

description.text:
Carriage plate and adaptors to fit an e3d v6 lite hotend to a ReRapPro Mendel printer.

Added new versions to give more clearance to hot end heater block as it was in danger of melting the carriage plate.

1B version moves hotend down another 5mm as my x axis rods were very close to the bed.

Bottom clamp goes against the carriage plate as this one is slightly taller than the top clamp to give more spacing.

Modified the carriage mount to move the extruder down another 5mm for clearance of bed clips and also added and arm which will depress the x carriage endstop.

print_settings.Notes:: Simple print, holes do not require infill, watch for warping on first layers.

description.text:
A Smoke Alarm and Remote Power Switch for 3D printers.

Provides a convenient wall mountable On off Switch for Printers such as the E3D that have a poorly positioned power switch.

Interfaces to a Smoke Alarm or Smoke Detector and cuts power to the printer if smoke is detected.

Smoke alarm functions as a regular Smoke alarm when printer is powered off.

Schematics and BOM to follow.

Printer:

E3D Bigbox

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Simple print, holes do not require infill, watch for warping on first layers.

WARNING

Look I'm only going to say this once, this project uses MAINS electricity (which depending on where you live is somewhere between 110 and 240v). It has to switch the LIVE feed of your printer, if you aren't experienced with working with MAINS voltages then PLEASE do not build this yourself, or give it to someone experienced to check before you plug it in.

Doing this badly may cause electrocution or a house fire, if in doubt please move on.

Bill of Materials

Smoke Alarm with relay output:

Recommended: Aico EI105R
eg: https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B003XN4RRI

Note if you do lots of dusty things like sawing/milling etc in the same space as your printer go for the Ionising version which is less sensitive but not so easily damaged by dusty environments
eg: https://www.amazon.co.uk/Aico-EI100R-Powered-Smoke-Alarm/dp/B003XN4RPA

Main Box:

2 of of GX12-4 4-Pin 12mm Aviation plugs 12mm Female plug Male chassis socket
eg: https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B00X77GNAE

1 of ASH-10DA 10A single phase solid state AC relay 3-32v trigger voltage
eg: https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B01M074Z1P

1 of PSU PCB MOUNT 12V, 0.4A VCP05US12 (works for 110 to 240v input)
eg: https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B00DLSL1EC

Assuming your printer has an IEC mains socket, a Male to female IEC lead.
eg: https://www.amazon.co.uk/C2G-Computer-Extension-IEC320C13-IEC320C14

Control Panel:

2 of 2.54mm pitch prototype board (stripboard) 50x70mm (or cut to size)
eg: https://www.amazon.co.uk/sourcingmap-Prototype-Veroboard-Stripboard-50mmx70mm/dp/B00HR6IK8O

1 of LM555 Timer IC
eg: https://www.amazon.co.uk/Single-Timer-Dual-Line-Package/dp/B00B2IIA3S

Resistors
2 of 10k and 2x 560ohm 1/4w is enough.
Just buy a kit
eg: https://www.amazon.co.uk/Saver-Resistor-Different-Resistance-Assortment/dp/B01KUEZIXE

2 of 12x12mm PCB push buttons
eg: https://www.amazon.co.uk/TOOGOO-Quality-Momentary-Tactile-Button/dp/B00MN91TD8

1 of Red and 1 of Green 3mm LED
eg: https://www.amazon.co.uk/Green-Yellow-Assorted-Emitting-Diodes/dp/B01F0TCXSW

Misc:

A handful of short (5mm) M3 and M2 screws

2 x 4 core cable, USB cables of the right length for the control panel and smoke alarm are perfect…just cut off the ends

Solder, Hookup wire (or TC wire) for prototype board

heatshrink (recommended but not essential)

Tools:

Soldering Iron
Drivers for M2 and M3 Bolts
HeatGun (recommended but not essential)
Wire Cutters
Multimeter (recommended for fault finding but not essential)
12v DC PSU (recommended for testing control panel but not essential)
Craft Knife (to clean up holes for buttons in front panel)

BOM Notes:

Not specifically recommending Amazon here, there are cheaper places to get this stuff, just used UK Amazon links for ease.

If you want to save money then use a plug in 12v wall wart style Power Supply from an old Router or something, aside from the Smoke alarm the PSU is the most expensive bit ! If you do that shout and I'll do a modified case to omit the space for the PSU. It's just more untidy that way as you need a separate power socket to run this (rather than it using power from the printers Power lead)

Nothing is that specific, if you use alternate equivalent parts it will likely work, but for the relay you may find the screw holes don't line up. The only critical things to fit the prints are the Aviation connectors, The 12mm PCB buttons, and the screw holes are perfectly positioned for the prototype PCB's I am recommending here (though you could cut regular stripboard to fit just as well)

Control Panel

Taking the Parts from the Control Panel section of the BOM above.

Assemble as per the schematic image included in this project, paying attention to the physical pinout of the LM555 as per datasheets and the polarity of the LED's.

Solder the 4 pin (USB cable) to the circuit with the colours as indicated in the schematic

To test panel apply 12VDC to the Red cable and Ground from your PSU to the Black Cable

If Panel is working, the green LED (LED1) should light and stay lit when the On button is pressed and released.

Then if the Test/Off button is pressed the Red LED (LED2) should light momentarily and the Green Light should go out.

Check the Output on the Green wire, this should measure 12V after the On button is pressed and stay at 12V until the Test/Off button is pressed when it should drop to near zero volts.

Check the White trigger wire from the Alarm.

When the Panel is on (Green LED1 is lit) if the white wire is touched to the RED wire then the Red LED2 should momentarily light up and the Green light should go out.

If these checks all pass then the panel is working. Solder one of the Aviation Plugs to the end of the cable paying special attention to the numbering of the Pins (they are numbered on the aviation plugs if you look carefully near the pins)

description.text:
Love the Makerfaire robot, but wanted it to print in less than half an hour with movable joints. I also wanted him to say HL ModTech on his chest and GO WO on his feet. =)

After a good bit of tinkering with MeshMixer and the new TinkerCAD beta I was able to come up with a version that is worth sharing.

The one in the picture is actually scaled up 10% as I found the stock size did not print perfect every time. Sometimes the walls were just too thin. This one has been bulletproof so far and still completes in about 30 min on my Replicator 2.

I am printing with PLA. I have tried the print on my 2x, but My heated bed is making that bottom layer pretty glossy and fused so the joints have never been movable there... I am pretty sure it is a bed height issue on my end though.

author: Saryn2

title: Knob for the lid of a (Creuset) pot

description.text:
The knob from a lid of a Le Creuset pot broke. Here is a new one.
I inserted a M6 nut in the knob. The M6 nut is 10mm between the flat sides of the hexagon and 5mm thick. There is 1mm room.
The trick is to pause the print when the cavity for the nut is complete.
have a look in your slicer and search the layer where the hexagon converts in a circle. It's just before the circle starts that you have to insert the following commands :

G91 ; relative positioning
G1 Z20 ; raise nozzle 20 mm can be more. just adapt
M117 Insert nut ; message on the LCD
M0 ; pause - continue with the pushbutton on your LCD or via Octoprint
G1 Z-20 ; back to printing position
G90 ; absolute positioning

I added my G-code file. Made for a 0,6mm nozzle and 0,2 mm layers
Stop is here just before starting layer 63

Printer:

FT5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2 mm

Infill:

60%

Notes:

Print in ABS!!!
temperature 100°C !!

description.text:
As much as I love 3D printing, I still don't fully trust it to support my 30 lbs. backpack. So for all of those out there like me who whose backpacks undergo more trauma than a HALO parachutist, here's an indestructible buckle.
New and improved adjustable backpack buckle. Works with flat straps up to 26 mm wide.
It uses 5 mm thick Delrin, but other materials can be used.

1) Lasercut each of the components from a 5mm thick material. You need to cut two side plates for a total of 5 pieces.
2) Assemble using a >35mm screw. You can either tap the material or use a nut on the other side.

This is a recut of sitts314's excellent TOS enterprise model. I was having problem printing the saucer without warping causing serious problems at smaller scales, so I broke off the saucer and sliced it horizontally. This requires more assembly, but makes the saucer look better. I also recut the nacelles and pylons, which should make that assembly slightly easier.

I've been focusing all my prints on relatively small scale, and as a result, assembly will require some sanding/filing to get all the pieces to fit together properly. The smaller the model, the more work to assemble.
Also try to make your slicer of choice output as thin of bottom layer possible.
There are simplified versions of the amplifier and dish that will be easier to print at small sizes.
I kept the scale of sitts314's source. If you're interested at other scales, this is the sizing for three common modeling scales:
1:3125 = 0.294 (this is the scale of the Starline 2500 gaming miniatures)
1:2500 = 0.363 (a small common trek modeling scale)
1:1600 = 0.574 (another common modeling scale) I wouldn't recommend trying anything lower than 1:3125.

author: dbendeke

description.text:
Watch here: https://youtu.be/iU-xaoOj5lU

3DPrintmas Day 3! This time we're adding on to a video I did previously where I modeled a PS4. So this time up we're doing the XBox One.

I created this in Fusion 360. This model was meant to be a small model to print easily rather than a full size and accurate replica. So there aren't any of the ports or anything on the back. But all of the logos and easily identifiable pieces are there.

Then I printed it out (settings below), and then I handed it off to my wife for painting. She sanded it a bit then primed it up. After that she sprayed it silver before painting the black on with a sponge. She did it in this order so she didn't have to in with a small paint brush to do the logos that were inset into the model.

Happy Printing!

Print Settings:
Printer: Da Vinci 1.0 Pro
Filament: Hatchbox PLA
Layer Height: 0.1mm
Infill: 20%
Supports: No
Raft: No

The scad file has a number of parameters that can be tweaked to achieve different snowflake effects.  
The back is inscribed with the year (2013).

title: Arduino Mega and RAMPS case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is heavily based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:863076 but is a complete rework and redraw to accommodate an 80mm fan, more ventilation slots and 5mm more height.

Other changes include the square 'hoops' along each side to cable tie cables to, the 12mm high standoffs, 3mm mounting bolts holes (recessed to prevent short circuits) increased size of the M3 nut holders and larger cable exits.

10/12/2016 - I uploaded an alternative back end for the box as this one gives better ribbon cable access for the LCD display and cable access generally.

30/06/2017 - I've uploaded a new set of sides. These are 15mm taller than the originals to allow more electronics to be crammed into the RAMPS case. They are identified as v1.6 (taller) in the file listing.

Other parts designed for my printers include:

title: TEVO Black Widow E3D V6 fan 40 mm RHS BLT front standard & Vulcano

description.text:
Tevo Black Widow right hand side heater 40 mm fan cooler for Regular or Vulcano E3D V6.

The purpose of the right hand side placing of the fan is double.
1] It is not blocking the nozle view.
2] The air is leaving from the left hand side into the open. If the air was conducted to the rear it bounces on the black X plate and can reach the nozzle area.

We are now on Version2 where we made some room for the filament clamp design from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1922880 by Gary K.

For optimal usage it can be combined with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1937134

We also turned around the mounting of the BLT and the springs so you can adjust them more easily from below.

Version with lower BL-Touch bracket is for the Vulcano version.
Designed to be used with the springs that come with the BL-Touch.
The use of the springs gives easier adjustments.

Small tab in front is to mount a 5 mm white LED which shine on the nozzle.

No extra hardware needed.

I printed in PETg with 0.4 mm nozzle with support on heat bed as this is the only filament I had.Can be printed in PLA too...........

Printer:

Tevo Black Widow

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

23%

Notes:

Print as is with supports on heatbed.

title: Saladin / Hermes class TOS Destroyer / Scout

description.text: Is your USS Enterprise print lonely? Could it use a little buddy? This is a kitbash of sitts314's excellent Enterprise to create the one nacelle ships of Franz Joseph's old school Star Fleet Technical Manual from the late 70's.

I've been focusing all my prints on relatively small scale, and as a result, assembly will require some sanding/filing to get all the pieces to fit together properly. The smaller the model, the more work to assemble.
Also try to make your slicer of choice output as thin of bottom as possible.
I kept the scale of sitts314's source. If you're interested at other scales, this is the sizing for three common modeling scales:
1:3125 = 0.294 (this is the scale of the Starline 2500 gaming miniatures)
1:2500 = 0.363 (a small common trek modeling scale)
1:1600 = 0.574 (another common modeling scale)
I wouldn't recommend trying anything lower than 1:3125.
The deflector dish may be more trouble than it's worth at any scale.

title: QUBD TwoPointFive-Up
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I kickstarted the QUBD OneUp, and my friend, the TwoUp. And of course part of the issues it had was massive Z sag, due to the design of the printer mainly with a heavy X gantry and only one Z stepper/leadscrew.

This is an attempt to donate my OneUp parts to his TwoUp to make a "Two point Five" version. that is exactly the same, with an added Z stepper and leadscrew.

I wanted to make this mostly compatible with stock One/Two-Up printers without moving inside parts around too much. I wanted to be able to have these parts printed from the printers in true RepRap type fashion, to upgrade themselves. Sadly, the OneUp will not be able to print some parts, but the TwoUp should have no problems.

If you wish to make this modification, I would suggest making sure that BOTH the Z stepper motors are the same. It might be easier to get a single stepper, and replace either the X, Y, or E stepper (and adjust voltage for it accordingly!). Then use said removed stepper as the second Z. I do not believe any changes to the driver current needs to happen.

Currently only the right motor mount plate is done.

TODO:

  • A way to connect the brass nut to the right side of the gantry
  • A custom Y adapter to chain the Z steppers together
  • TESTING!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10% honeycomb

Notes:

For the upper leadscrew brace, make sure you have bridging tuned well. Otherwise, feel free to scale it up a bit for slop. This part has a built in support, so extra supports are not needed.

Filing

A fair bit of filing of the printed part to connect with the MDF on the One/Two-up without destroying the MDF.

I had to file every part that interlocked with the MDF as well as the middle stepper hole.

Adding the new motor mount

Carefully remove the upper and side plates for the bottom right part of the printer.
To do this, you will need to unscrew the smooth rod and pop apart the front/back parts of the base.

Remove the upper plate on the right side, as well as the right plate. These will no longer be needed!

After filing, carefully place the new motor mount where the upper plate that was removed, and interlock with the MDF. DO NOT FORCE IT, as you could ruin the MDF of the rest of the machine!

If wished, you can re-insert the side plate to separate the steppers, but it is not needed.
Insert the new stepper from below and screw it in.

Merging of STL files

I borrowed the STL files from fuco, who converted the official dxf files.
I merged the plates for the upper part of the base together to create an extended plate for the right side using Fusion360.

comments.text: Very nice. I am printing the parts for this upgrade while I wait for the new motors, lead screws and couplers to arrive. I had to modify the "top plate" as it would not slice correctly in S3D.
comments.author: Jakontheroad

comments.text: It is probably because I merged a STL with a modified version of itself in fusion.  I guess this means I need to finish the second z axis mount soon, since that is not published yet.  I should have time to get that done this week.

description.text:
For #3DPrintingDay 2016 I wanted to share a few designs that have helped me out with 3D Printing. Mostly, it's about having a place for everything I use. Blue tape is one of those daily tools so lets make a home for it!

This was the third or so iteration of this design, I'm happy with where it is so here you go!

A few design aspects:
With PLA, it had a suitable bend to the bracket. The angle braces keep the strength and stiffness, while the center where the mounting screw goes does all the flexing. So be aware of this when you mount the bracket.
Don't screw it in too tight:
1) because it's a 3d printed plastic part and you'll crack it,
and
2) because you might want to play around with screw tightness. I found a nice middle ground where the the bracket still bends, but doesn't rotate when I remove or put back the tape.

Happy #3dprinting!

Get it printed at our 3DHub: https://www.3dhubs.com/boston/hubs/ag3d-printing

Da Vinci Pro 3-in-1

title: vibrating balls toy - silicone molding form

description.text:
This is a molding form generator for the "vibrating balls" siicone toy.

You can adjust the size of the balls, the height and radius of the base and some more parameters. Use tinkering wire to fasten both parts together. Then you can pour silicone in and wait until it is solid. Then remove the tinkering wire and carefully open the form.

For more information see http://www.bodyinteraction.com
Deatiled building instructions: https://bodyinteraction.com/2016/12/14/openscad-as-silicone-molding-form-generator/

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

30%

Notes:

XYZ printer daVinci 1.0

comments.text:
I know I commented on another of your models but forgot to respond to your own questions.
To get a better finish to the final toy, brush the inside of the mold with acetone, that'll help smooth out the ridges made by the printer. You'll get a nice shiny finish.
https://goo.gl/photos/bt3ApHH2EFvS4trT6 (Shows with and without smoothing.)
One method to help prevent silicon from oozing bewteen the molds is to sand the matching surfaces. I found a sheet of 600 grit sandpaper on something like glass or other very flat surface does a good job. I makemy molds much more solid so I can clamp them. In your case if you move the holles closer to the edges of the form and use small bolts that might also work and use a lot less plastic, at the cost of more time.
Here are some more pictures. https://goo.gl/photos/QeSPV3tGNw1MyUzH6

title: Snap On SSD 418 Screwdriver Handle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The handle on my old Snap On SSD 418 screwdriver shattered one day when I dropped it off the deck. This is a 24 inch long screwdriver that I have had since I worked as a mechanic before college. This thing got a lot of use, so I hated to lose it. Being a Snap On tool, it has a lifetime warranty, but when I contacted Snap On I discovered it was obsolete and handles were no longer available. They replaced it with their latest model, but it is much longer and frankly not as functional so, when I got my 3D printer I naturally decided I could reclaim my old friend by making a new handle.

Mine is made from Nylon for strength, durability and impact resistance. Since I don't have the original to go by, I looked up some used ones on e-bay for the basic design and made it as long as my CEL-Robox would allow me to print. It could stand to be a little longer, but it is close to the original size.

title: Eyelid latch for Funhouse / Roadshow pinball machine

description.text:
I have a Funhouse pinball machine made by Williams in 1989. A while back, Rudy's eyes stopped opening and closing, which turned out to be caused by a broken plastic part. After nearly 30 years, I don't know if this part is available anywhere, but it seemed like a perfect opportunity to use my 3D printer for something useful.

[The same part is installed in both Red and Ted in Roadshow.]

Notes:

  1. Important: Units in this model are inches, so you may have to scale it by 25.4 in all dimensions if your software is expecting mm.
  2. You'll need to print this with supports, because the round part is elevated above the bed.
  3. Print at high infill for strength -- I used 60%.
  4. The part prints upside down. Be sure to install it correctly -- the top during printing should be the bottom during use.
  5. The part is held into the solenoid plunger by a 1/16" roll pin. This hole is so small that I didn't bother to include it in the design. Instead, I used a #53 drill to drill the hole after installing the part into the plunger, then pushed the pin into place.
  6. For maximum strength, I aligned the part in the plunger so that the hole goes from top to bottom, not side to side. I feel this will be stronger and less likely to break.

PS: They are still available for $4.50 at http://www.marcospecialties.com/pinball-parts/03-8480. #03-8480 LINK PLASTIC - EYE

author: jeplans

description.text: Star Trek's Miranda Class Starship. This is a modification and cutup of Serin117's USS Vigilant, with some of the 24th century modifications removed.

The detail level on Serin's model is really perfect for smaller prints, so this came out really well. I've been focusing all my prints on relatively small scale, and as a result, assembly will require some sanding/filing to get all the pieces to fit together properly. The smaller the model, the more work to assemble. Also try to make your slicer of choice output as thin of bottom as possible. I kept the scale of Serin117's source. If you're interested at other scales, this is the sizing for three common modeling scales: 1:3125 = 0.49 (this is the scale of the Starline 2500 gaming miniatures)
1:2500 = 0.613 (a small common trek modeling scale)
1:1600 = 0.958 (another common modeling scale) I wouldn't recommend trying anything lower than 1:3125.

For #3DPrintingDay 2016 I wanted to share a few designs that have helped me out with 3D Printing. Mostly, it's about having a place for everything I use. I use a lot of glue stick on any day when PLA is involved...which is alot of them.

I wanted to make a little holder to put inside my Da Vinci Pro 3-in-1. It's pretty discrete, which is nice. And I just used water washable glue to stick it to the bed. That way, I can always remove it and the printer doesn't look like I glue something to it.

If you want a tighter snug to the peg, I would print it 5-10% larger. Try 105% first, I personally have not printed this at a bigger size. The 100% version is just a simple peg for the glue stick to stand up on

description.text:
I liked CarryTheWhat's spinner toy that they have published here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1871997

But given that roller bearings can be a little scarce, I wanted to use some mass that was more readily available. I also wanted some more practice developing 'if...else' loops in OpenSCAD.

So I present MoneySpinner, a collection of spinner toys that use appropriately sized and globally available coins as the spinning mass.

Depending on your country, you can download an STL to print that uses readily available coins that (hopefully) press fit into the holders. The STLs have the coin type followed by the number of spokes in their filenames.

The OpenSCAD file caters for between two and seven spokes and the following coins:

  • Australian $2
  • Australian 5c
  • US 10c (dime)
  • UK £1
  • UK 5p
  • EU €1
  • US 1c, and
  • US 5c (nickel).

I have now uploaded the scad file into the Customizer. Please tell me how it works out for you. Additionally, I have uploaded a selection of STLs to cater for most people's desires.

Most options accommodate two coins in each 'stack'. When using AU 5c, US 10c and UK 5p, three coins per stack can be fitted. I have sourced the dimensions (diameter and thickness) from reliable sources on the web but if you print one of these and have major problems fitting the coins, please provide me with feedback.

I have also used the excellent knurling function provided by aubenc's library here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:32122

Update 9: Added 6902 bearing option. This is a larger bearing with a 28mm outer diameter. There are also STLs for a hub for this bearing.

Update 8: '1' as an option for 'number of spokes' now available for an out of balance spinner.

Update 7: Finally got a hub designed and uploaded.

Update 6: Bugfix. US Nickel now correct for 3 coin stacks.

Update 5: Orbits! The customizer now offers orbits as an option for increased strength and good looks!

Update 4: US 1c added as requested. Qatari 50 dirham deleted to keep menus simple.

Update 3: Now includes a smooth edge option for those with soft fingers! Look for the 3 spoke US 5c STL and the Smooth option in the Customizer.

Update 2: I deleted the CR2032 option in case someone sets fire to themselves. Instead, as requested there is now a US 5c (Nickel) option. It assumes stacks of 4 (as requested). Tell me if this doesn't work. It seems like you will need long fingers!

Update 1: I have printed a number of these now.Tolerances are fairly tight, an Australian $2 fits well but the 5 cent coin has a tendency to break through one or more ring as the 3 coins are pressed in. My solution has been to scale the STL up by 100.5% in Simplify 3D when I make my gcode. 101% made the bearing a bit loose. Your mileage may vary.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I use a raft to ensure adhesion without a heated bed. As these are only several millimetres thick, it is important to ensure they remain attached throughout the print.

I designed this using OpenSCAD. The current code incorporates switches that select the number of spokes (between 2 and 7) and the coin type by name. The dimensions of individual coin types are hard coded and selected automatically through an if...else sequence.

A 'spoke' is built using a knurled disk of appropriate dimensions with a void and attached to an 'arm' which is proportional to the coin diameter.

The length of the spoke is dependent on the dimensions of the coin and must be able to be spun between a thumb and finger without hitting the web in between. I think a €1 coin, which has a diameter of 23.3mm is the limit and may be too big for many people.

The spoke is then rotated by the appropriate angle using a for() loop and attached to a hub that is appropriate for a standard 22mm rollerskate bearing.

remixed_from.title: DVD, Cable Box, DVR, Above TV Adjustable Angle Shelf VESA 200mm Flat Panel HDTV

description.text:
Designed for mounting an Xbox One Kinect on top of TV. Connecting to the Wall Mounts behind TV. There is a 1/4" diameter hole in the middle of the platform designed to use a standard 1/4" diameter, 20 threads per inch bolt for Kinect. 3 separate files are designed to fit with a Makerbot 2/2X. Thank you to jevs for the original design. Update
I modified the 2 Brackets, Top half did not print correctly. Optimized bottom half for a faster print.
Update 2
Added a second bracket for those who have larger TVs

Infill: 10%
Shells: 2
Layer Height: 0.30mm As a tip, when printing the Mount Plate. Pay special attention when leveling the Build plate. You want to be as accurate as possible. Since this print takes up most of the printing surface, if it's off by just a bit it will screw up the first critical layer. To Put this together You will need the Following: -All 3 Printed items
  • (1) 1/4"x1/2" 6.4 Screw (Standard Tripod Screw)
    *Purchased at Home Depot Part, Dr# - 406
  • (2) M8 - 1.25x30mm Socket Cap Screw (For Mounting to VESA mount on TV)
    Purchased at Home Depot Part, #803418
    -(6) 1/4" 20 x 1-1/4", Screws and Screw Nuts (For putting base and bracket together)
    Purchased at Home Depot Part, 28771

author: Kuon

description.text:
I manage to get this running with these parts, the buggy isn't a great design, it works but it's not durable, the steering lock is awful and the gears are really noisy. But hopefully with these parts you'll be able to get this working.

I've uploaded:

Driveshafts - the original designs calls for a threaded bar with 3d printed ends and grub screws. Too many parts, too much to go wrong so I simplified it, now the shafts only require grub screws and they work.

Gears - I reworked the gear set to take M5 nuts, this means you press the nuts in and you can screw them onto the threaded bar and bolts rather than relying on glue. also I included some M5 spacers to ensure everything stays lined up and meshed.

Wheels - the originals require some weird size tyres, I made my own to take standard 26mm tyres you can find for pennies on ebay/amazon etc.

Arches and light bar - because they look cool.

remixed_from.author: Tripnutz
remixed_from.title: MY FAV PI ( raspberry pi 2/3 case )

description.text:
I added a small ridge on the top part edge off Tripnutz great design. Together with a small adaption on the bottom it enables the bottom to be clicked in the top and thus fixated. I also added a few small feet printed in ninjaflex. This will lift the case about 1.5mm up so that the bottom has sufficient airflow for the chip on the bottom of the pi. For most application I do not think a fan is necessary so I took the liberty to adapt a second top with a pi logo.
I printed it in PLA 0.1mm. It proved to be a good addition. The bottom is well fixated but it can still be easily disassembled.

The ninja flex feet are about 0.2mm oversized in in comparison to the mounting holes,so that they fit in tight,You may have to enlarge the holes a little to get them in.
I made the wall for the connectors a little thicker and added some support under the HDMI hole just cut it out.

print_settings.Notes:: This thing needs to have a high density in a strong plastic, so that it can withstand the abuse of having threads cut into it. I suppose PLA would work, as long as you're gentle, but then too I have to question the sanity of making bolts out of PLA, I'd sooner go with something a bit more exotic like PETG, Nylon or Polycarbonate. Print it dense and fairly hot for good layer adhesion, and with a little luck and effort you can come away with some useful little plastic bolts cut to your own specs. Good luck!
print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

description.text:
Hello again, dear readers. I decided to just throw this out there, Earth shattering as it is. It's just an unthreaded bolt blank, a stopover on the way to experiments with fully threaded, printed bolts. You may ask, "Why oh why did you not simply post a fully threaded bolt? WHY THIS UNTHREADED CRAP???". And I'd be like, "Chill. It's useful." Actually, it is MORE useful than a finished bolt. This thing, you can rescale to any head/shaft size you like, and using simple die tools, tap your OWN threads onto it for your own purposes. Small threadings are notoriously hard to print unless you have a truly special printer, so as long as your blank is strong enough to take the abuse of cutting, you'll actually get better results from cutting the threads by hand, provided your print quality and material is up to it.

Why use plastic bolts at all? I'll grant you that metal, functionally, will beat plastic just about any day of the week, but I can throw you five instances where plastic is just better:

1) Weight sensitive applications such as drone usage.
2) Magnetism sensitive applications.
3) Electrically sensitive applications.
4) Any application where surfaces may be damaged by the strength and hardness of metal bolts.
5) Thermal conductivity sensitive applications.

Default dimensions of this bolt blank are:

10mm head width
3.7mm head height
6mm shaft diameter
27mm shaft length

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm - 0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

This thing needs to have a high density in a strong plastic, so that it can withstand the abuse of having threads cut into it. I suppose PLA would work, as long as you're gentle, but then too I have to question the sanity of making bolts out of PLA, I'd sooner go with something a bit more exotic like PETG, Nylon or Polycarbonate. Print it dense and fairly hot for good layer adhesion, and with a little luck and effort you can come away with some useful little plastic bolts cut to your own specs. Good luck!
Who says I did? Kidding. I did. Well, the Elves did. Those mofos be crazy this week.

title: Moving Arms - Stuck in Chimney Santa

description.text:
Santa is stuck in a Chimney. He is waving his arms for help. Pull on the 2013 (more sayings will be added soon) and his arms will wave for help. Now includes 2015 version. See video of the arms moving here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nh90FEFuH-s See video of how to assemble the ornament here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cIk6iy-pieQ

The body needs supports for the void which holds the arm mechanism.  
Adding a cooling tower (primer pillar) is a good idea for the connector and back.  This allows the pins to cool before the next layer.  
To hang it on the tree add a string through the hole on the top of the Santa hat.

title: Customisable Flower Pot, bowl or vase

description.text:
I made this because I needed a square flower pot that was 75 cm at the top and 60 cm at the bottom. Such a flower pot fits perfectly in my HerbGarden hydroponic system.

But why not make it parametric so that you can make the flower pot you need? You can choose size, what shape you want, if you want a brim at the top and if you want perforations at the bottom and/or at the sides.

Because of the level of customisation you can make more than flower pots with this one. Basically a range of cups, vases and bowls.

I usually print them 1.5 mm thick and with no support.

The measures for my two hydroponic systems are:
FreshGarden Max: Round, bottom = 56 mm, top = 71, height = 70 mm, brim and perforations on bottom and sides, 1.5 mm thick.

HerbGarden (Tregren Herbie): Square, bottom = 60, top = 75, height = 75, no brim, no perforation on the sides, perforation at the bottom, 1.5 mm thick.

comments.text: Love the fact this is customisable.  Only thing missing is the ability to add feet, so you get the advantage of slots in the base allowing the drainage of water, could you add this?  :-D
comments.author: djjones253

comments.text: Good idea. I have now added an experimental option to add four 5 mm feet to the model. Let me know how it works.
comments.author: djjones253

comments.text: Is there any chance of a central foot as well please?  In bigger sizes the heavier plants/soil need central support.  Sorry I know more about plant pots than 3D printing, I'm new and having a go!
comments.author: eirikso

comments.text: Remember that you need to print it with "support material" if you choose the one with feet.
comments.author: djjones253

comments.text: A central foot as well is a good idea. I have added that now. Experimental and untested, but looks OK.
comments.author: djjones253

comments.text: Thank you, it's next on my list to have a go at when I finish what I'm printing now!

author: arigert

description.text:
The drain in my kitchen sink was very annoying. If I left too many things in the sink (as I am wont to do), invariably something would push the strainer down and make it close off the drain. Water amasses, and my delicate hands are forced to plunge in and resolve the issue.

I rarely ever need to stop the drain, so I made this.

It is 82mm in diameter and 6mm thick. Scale it to fit your drain. I wouldn't make it too tight of a fit either. I made mine a little smaller than the drain, so I can pull it out without a handle.

I'd also recommend not using a raft, unless your settings are really dialed in. All of the holes make removing a stuck raft tedious.

Printer:

Mendelmax 3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

75%

description.text:
This is a single pistol holder.

Some things about the holder. The barrel rest is a little low which allowed me to place a soft rest at the bottom of it. This put it at a good height for my use. The holes you see throughout are not for looks, but was there to save on plastic.

I printed as follows:

Nozzle - .4
Filament - Inland PLA
Layer Height .3
Infill 10%
Printer: Original Prusa i3 MK2
Print Time: ~4 hours

Edit: I found that the posts can be a little weak. So it might be good to print at 10% on the body, but at a higher % just before the posts to the top of the print.

author: mrjefferson105

description.text: NCC 1701 movie era constitution class. Cut up and ready to print.

I've been focusing all my prints on relatively small scale, and as a result, assembly will require some sanding/filing to get all the pieces to fit together properly. The smaller the model, the more work to assemble. Preparing the pylons to intersect the secondary hull can result in a lot of sanding. The more time you take on this, the better your results will be. Also try to make your slicer of choice output as thin of bottom as possible. This model is a combination of two versions I found on the net, combined to bypass problems I ran into trying to convert each to printable versions: Saucer - http://sketchup.google.com/3dwarehouse/details?mid=22e40224647d9e151acbc73f01a6e85f&ct=mdrm&prevstart=0 Hull - Eric Peterson's "U.S.S. Enterprise-A" found at http://www.trekmeshes.ch/ (direct linking not allowed) If you're interested in modeling scales, this is the sizing for three common scales: 1:3125 = 0.428 (this is the scale of the Starline 2500 gaming miniatures)
1:2500 = 0.535 (a small common trek modeling scale)
1:1600 = 0.836 (another common modeling scale) I wouldn't recommend trying anything lower than 1:3125. UPDATE: The Saucer from Eric Peterson's model is better, and I was finally able to generate a printable STL, so I've included that as the "_ALT" saucer. The combined model stl is Peterson's.

comments.text: I tried to print this at 1/3125 scale to match up with my ADB Star Fleet Battles minis in ABS. Sadly, at that scale, the warp nacelle pylons were too thin to support the weight of the engines.
comments.author: siefertma

comments.text: I haven't done 1/3125, but I have printed the parts at 1/5000 with these files, and aside from getting the parts off the bed I didn't have any strength issues in ABS. Can you try printing the nacelle and pylon parts as 100% infill if you're not already? Also consider adding a tenth of a mm to your first layer height when slicing, which might give it the strength it needs.
comments.author: siefertma

comments.text: Indeed, you are quite correct, although there was the FASA "Enterprise Class" heresy of the 80's that caused much fandom confusion(for the full background, see http://en.memory-alpha.org/wiki/Enterprise_class ). Still, in-line with the US Navy’s Essex class refit (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Essex-class_aircraft_carrier#Post-war_rebuilds ), which was radical but didn’t change the class name (and trek was heavily influenced by WWII and post-war US Navy), I believe "Constitution Class Refit" is the proper name.

remixed_from.author: sn3850
remixed_from.title: Complete Biker Scout armor Star Wars

description.text:
After printing part of the helmet from the design I remixed this from, I weighed the colossal support structure and it weighed in at a whopping 140g!!!! I decided to tweak the design slightly, removing the top of the helmet from the part of the shell below it, meaning it only needed a minimal structure under it to make it print nicely!

This design saved me approximately 9 hours print time and 140g of filament (as I'd already printed part 2) , but if you used this design for both part 2 and part 3, it would save you 18 hours and 280g of filament!!!

To help with scaling this for a good fit, I've also included an assembled 3D file of the helmet - simply scale this until the measurements will fit your head, and then use the multiplication factor (i.e. if you scale it to your measurements as a whole, and find it to be 1.05x scale) to scale the individual pieces, or in Cura just right click and press "Seperate into Parts" to dismantle it.

NOTE: Don't make my mistake, check that your head will fit through the hole at the bottom, not just inside!

Credit to Rafa92 for the finished photo - still haven't painted mine

Fits a door hinge between the hinge and the door jamb

It's summer again, and in this 100-year old house, that means the wood expands, and doors may or may not fit any more.
This is a simple, flat shim for (re)leveling doors and fitting them to their frames.
Push-pull in Google Sketchup is tremendously handy for making any width you need.

This cover is designed to snap firmly over the v-slots of aluminum extrusions. (2020, 2040, etc) This can be done for either aesthetic reasons, or to conceal wiring ran through the slots. Because of the small details of this design, I recommend printing in .1mm detail. These parts have a nice, firm fit. They should snap right in with a firm push.

While not a direct remix (I designed these from scratch), after a failed previous design (one which had to slide in from the end), I did draw inspiration from this thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:944921 (I had difficulty getting this one to stay in place, and it kept popping out.)

title: Tevo Tarantula Large Bed Glass Corner Brackets retainers

description.text:
Could'nt find any brackets for the large bed Tevo Tarantula, so I made these up. You dont have to remove the screw's to install if you want to fight the bed springs. Also there is front brackets and rear brackets since the screws are in different places. Print in ABS or something that can deal with higher heat than PLA, I am just using the PLA as a test.
The brackets I added holes for 3mm screws to help stabilize the glass without having it actually clamped to the bed.
I noticed using binder clips that as the aluminum bed would heat up and deform the glass would also slightly deform if its thin enough. one of the main reason's I came up with this design to avoid that from occurring.

Just a note:

Don't troll on other peoples design's, like someone else is attempting to do too me on this design. Make improvements, redesign, contribute that's what this place is for. Good discussion about the design and respectful criticism is all good as well. But if your gonna roll into someones design thinking you are better than anyone else and bash on it, forget about it and move along.

Tevo owners that have the larger bed option will know why I designed this.

Like it says at the top "Hey this thing is a work in progress"

comments.text: Would be nice if the L/R files were actually just left and right rather than both together. Otherwise, not a bad design if a little sense is used in regards to tightening the screws.
comments.author: swartlkk

comments.text: they have worked fine so far but definitely could be improved upon. I haven't went back to the file since I put them up. I will look at it when I can and separate them out.  I only used the screws to lightly rest against the edge of the glass to help keep it from moving.
comments.author: swartlkk

comments.text: Bad design. A good way to chip the glass bed !
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
Well don't over tighten it. I have it set just enough so the glass doesn't move. I haven't chipped the glass. If you can come up with a better design cool, it would be nice to see what others come up with. Everyone seems to be making these for the standard size bed but there hasn't been any for the large bed.
Did you end up trying this out? Or did you just want to put in your two cents?
If you noticed at the top of the page it does say that this thing is still in the works. Was hoping for some ideas on the design or someone to remix it.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
Indeed I made a better design months ago but didn't publish it as It's so simple I didn't dare publish and it doesn't use printed parts.
But as I see plenty of wrong or over complicated designs, I decided to publish it.
BTW yours not only risk to chip the glass but to raise the glass a few tenth from the base plate !
Bedsize doesn't matter.
Also, here is a good one, not from me but using printed parts: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1947870

description.text:
This is a complete ball-and-stick model of tRNA-Phe (PDBID: 1EHZ). Each nucleotide has been split up into the sugar-phosphate backbone and the nucleobase to make printing easier. In cases where there are mostly planar base pairs, both nucleobases are in the same model. Pins and holes allow assembly. Filenames that have 'cube' in them refer to hydrogen bonds that are to be printed separately. A complete model (trna.stl) is included so you can see how it all goes together.

Recommending scaling: 700% (in mm scale)

MakerBot

remixed_from.title: Raspberry Pi 3, Pi 2, and Model B+ case with VESA mounts and more

description.text:
This is a remix of one of my favorite Raspberry Pi cases. I wanted to use this case to house my Octopi setup, and have it mounted to my printer, which uses 2020 and 2040 aluminum extrusions. I needed to modify the case a bit in order to mount to the v-slots. I had to remove the existing mounting holes and wings. Also had to remove one of the holes used to attached the top to the bottom. Along the flat side, I added recessed spaces for M3 bolts. I've included an M3 t-nut, which I got from thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1073567

To mount the case to the v-slot, print two of the M3 T-Nuts. You will then need 2 M3 nuts to press fit into the T-Nuts. You will also need 2 M3 x 6mm bolts.

author: steeves

description.text: SNOWMAN COOKIE CUTTER
Most famously appearing (briefly before going kablooey due to Klingon shenanigans) as the USS Grissom in Star Trek III

This is based on the "U.S.S. Grissom" model I found here: http://www.trekmeshes.ch To get a clean print I broke it up into a large number of parts. I've been sticking with 1:2500 prints for ship models, which for this is quite small (~6cm). Still, I think it came out quite well. You should print two copies of the nacelle, as they are identical. Unlike all the other ships I've cut up, there aren't clear connection points for the nacelles and saucer, so you'll need to eyeball the correct place to glue them together. Note that the way I've cut up the model, connecting the primary and secondary hull can be... challenging. A larger model may be easier to assemble. STL is in 1:2500 scale.

print_settings.Notes:: Model has a tendency to pop off the bed. Take proper steps.

description.text:
This is a 3D version of the 7th iteration of the Heighway dragon curve. Multiple copies of the model may be used to demonstrate that the dragon curve tiles the plane.
(N.L., MAT 363, December 2015)

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes:

Model has a tendency to pop off the bed. Take proper steps.

Put em together!

Since the dragon is self-similar, one may assemble multiple copies of this model into a larger but similar version - or just keep tiling.

To create the 2d dragon curve in a printable format that can be tiled together I
determined I could create a polyline of the curve in Rhinoceros and from there quickly sweep the curve to create the printable object. I intended to be able to produce any iteration (up to computational limits) of the dragon curve so I needed some way to automate the process, rather than entering all the points by hand. To create such an automation, I utilized Rhinoceros' python integration.
(N.L., MAT 363, December 2015)

More Details: Mathematics Behind the Design

The python implementation utilizes a specific understanding of the construction of the
Heighway dragon curve. Effectively, to construct this curve we start with a straight line
segment and proceed by duplicating our curve and rotating it 90 degrees around the end of our curve. To implement this, I just need to list the first two points in my curve and proceed with the algorithm. It was necessary to use the rotation matrix for R2. For computational eciency, instead of using matrix multiplication my program directly
converted a point (x; y) into (-y; x). Note that this matrix rotates around the origin. Thus,
our algorithm will need to translate our curve so it ends at the origin. From here, it is
simple to sweep the curve with a rectangle to produce a 3-dimensional object that can be
printed. Unfortunately, the object is not yet fit for tiling because corners would overlap.
To allow the object to demonstrate a tiling it was necessary to curve the corners using the
FilletCorners command. This will bring the corners in enough to prevent overlap, so long as we choose a suitable width rectangle to sweep the curve with for the given iteration.
(N.L., MAT 363, December 2015)

Keep your support materials
Krazy glue them to a piece of styrene
Spray it all matte black
Then with a grey spray
Then a light dusting of black again
When dry start white gluing on bits of green moss from a hobby shop. I also used some terracotta rubble.

This is a remix of the Holiday Lantern with Swappable Panels by dehart007

Liked the idea but had a kind of hard time getting the top section to print nice so I redesigned it to print the top and bottom separately. Depending on your printer they will probably be a snug fit.

I also added a cylinder for the tea light cover. "Tea light cover test". It is intended to be printed in spiral vase mode with 0 bottom layers, 0 top layers 0 infill and 1 shell. Print with a 1 layer brim with 10 to 12 outlines to help keep it stuck to the bed.

The original model for the rest of the files is http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:537132

All measurements were taken from the original design so the panels and top should fit the same.

This is my first ever attempt at a remix and first time uploading something.

title: Polaris RZR  XP Infinity Stereo Dash Mounting Plate Updated

description.text:
If you don't have V1.4 file, download and replace the original. After printing and installing the hinge pin tabs were slightly off. This update fixes the issue.

This plate replaces the hinged dry box door in the dash and is sized to fit the Infinity PVR models of marine audio units.

I made this for a RZR 1000 XP, and an Infinity PVR250 stereo, but the same box is used in other years and those who have added the stock Polaris double din dry box on older RZR models.

Remove the box from the dash, push out the 2 plastic hinge pins and remove the door. Replace the door with this face plate. Reinstall the 2 plastic pins through the tabs. Drill 2 small holes in the top edge of the box and secure (into the new panels extrusion with small sheet metal screws to secure the unit to box. Restall the box and you have a neat, cleanly mounted in-dash stereo. Use a color that coordinates with your RZR paint or make it black like the dash.

title: Bowden tube fitting wrench for XYZ Da Vinci 1.0 Pro

description.text:
This fitting wrench allows you to replace the bowden tube fitting attached near the extruder motor without having to remove all the covers of the xyz printer. Simply lift the top cover, remove the bowden tube and filament, and insert the wrench (line the notch up with one of the corners) and turn left to unscrew the fitting. This wrench has been tested with the original fitting that comes with the machine and uxcell fittings found on amazon: https://www.amazon.com/dp/B009ITFXDI/

There are three wrenches, an all in one that requires no additional tools, a bit that can be used with a standard bit driver, and a socket that can be used with a standard 3/8" socket wrench.

The parts were successfully printed on a XYZ Pro in 0.5mm, 1mm, and 2mm using Simplify3D for slicing. I recommend using 1mm or better due to the chamfered edges at the opening. I also recommend printing slow especially near the opening due to the extremely thin walls. Supports are only needed for the bit version (depending on orientation).

The parts may need sanding or finishing, at least around the exterior tube especially if there are blobs or strings.

I hope this helps save you time when replacing your fittings.

title: Hot Shoe Speedlight Mount (remixed mic mount)

description.text:
Updated schematic, very simple!

So I have always wanted to 3d print something for my Nikon ever since i got it. With a 3D printer and a love for photography I knew I had to do something awesome! I have a dinky little micro printer though, so printing big stuff was out.... When i saw the challenge and the source material I was inspired to design. I don't have/use a mic but i also don't own a speed light. So i decided my build platform is just big enough and my self taught electronic skills are just good enough to do this. My 3D design work is always a work in progress though.. So I used the http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:346513 for my inspiration. I couldn't modify it but i measured it and used the measurements to sketch one up. I changed the base to include the holes for the hotshoe which are 1.5mm in diameter. I got the measurements for the distance between the holes from my own Nikon. I added a hole next to the hole used to lock attachments onto the hotshoe, to connect a pin to ground. I used my measurements from the hotshoe mic mount. I added some girth to the bottom of the hotshoe mount to not only support the light but also house the perf board which i connected my spring pins (http://www.ebay.com/sch/sis.html?_nkw=100Pcs+0.99mm+Diameter+Spherical+Tip+Spring+Testing+Probe+Pins&_id=231026502173&&_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2658) to for my electrical connections. I gave the top part enough internal space to house a 9v battery and the electronics along with the trim-potentiometers to change the resistance of the amount of power going to the RGB LEDs for color mixing. I would have done an arduino version but the quickness needed for a flash is too fast for an arduino, Unless it was just for complete a separate led circuit, which i didn't think of until writing this. I may have more iterations to come.... The hotshoe on nikon can ground a couple hundred volts i read, so for LEDs, which don't require anything near that, my circuit is fine. I googled a lot of stuff about how the pins work. Basically other than all the communication pins, the center pin is connected to the grounding bracket when the shutter is released. So completing a simple circuit would not be difficult. The mounting hole for the hinge is 3.5mm. The prints i made are rough, but thats due to a cheap 3d printer thats on its way out. The top part alone for my printer is on hour 23 and is only 80% done. But the files are sound. I will be using a hot glue gun to press LEDs into place. I don't have a light reflector but I'm sure one can be added. The mic hot shoe could still very well be used, but i wanted mine to have a little more body to it as to not directly expose the wire or look like a minimalist project. Enjoy! I'll also try answering as many questions as possible!

Also: i just added a schematic for the circuit (pdf in thing files) i built to fit inside. I did my best to label anything. All of the parts can be ordered cheaply online.

Black ABS at 275C
Printed on sides to make sure crevice lines were smooth.

Setup post-printing

I cut perf board to 14x16mm and stacked two off them. I then drilled between two of the holes in the perf board to add the space for the center pin. The drill bit used was 1.5mm. Soldered the pins into the perf board once the perf board was inside the mount, and connected two wires. The spring tip sticks out of the bottom of the board about 1mm.

IMPORTANT!!!
Before putting all the pieces together, after soldering pins, check connection on breadboard. The pins could possibly not be touching camera connector pins and it won't work.
For the LEDs I pre soldered perf board prior to printing. used a 2.5mm hex bolt and nut for mounting top to base. I lightly sanded the back piece to have a smoother fit to slide in. Pressed LED board into place, hot glued sides to hold LEDs. I placed in the rest of the circuit with the battery and slid back piece into place. turned on power to lights and took a pic.

The schematic shows a switch. In place of the switch is the cameras hotshoe. Positive to center pin and GND pin to BC547 base.

Parts:
1x BC547
1x 1500uF 16v Electrolytic capacitor
1x 1n4002 Rectifier diode
LEDs and resistors for LEDs

I remixed the adjustable hotshoe microphone holder.

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:346513
After adding this to 123D design app i took measurements and created a side by side comparison. I then changed the top to allow electronic internals to be constructed and laid within. I made enough room for a 9v battery to be able to fit inside and set the holes for the hotshoe at the appropriate distance.

LEDs won't light.
If there is no transfer of power between LEDs they won't light up. The problem i ran into was the pins from the base to the camera. I hadn't put them down far enough to touch the camera connections on the hotshoe.

Im going to work on upgrading the circuit. The LEDs are not high power LEDs. I have a few 1W and 3W LEDs that ill work on a circuit for.
I'll also work on changing the shape; make it cooler looking than just a box.
I'll work toward making this a ring light as well for macro photography

I'm new to 3D printing and I'm very impressed with the community here at Thingiverse, so I want to give something back.

While I don't have any nice 3D work to share, as an engineer I tried to imagine an alternative 3D printer design, and I came up with this one.

This is my basic design for a mostly printable 3D printer.

To be honest I didn't do an extensive search to see if similar designs exist, but nonetheless I release this idea to the public.

It consist of two main rotating bodies, one that is the “dish” print surface (A) and the “arm” (B). The arm harbors the “hand” (C) which can move up/down (Z axis). The intermeshing of the rotating bodies provide the two degrees of freedom required for the X and Y components.

The strengths of the design are:
1) simple to assemble and robust
2) It can be almost completely 3d printed
3) Multiple arms can be added (up to four in total) and combined with additional dishes and heads to allow simultaneous build of up to 4 identical prints
4) Should make less noise as it mostly rotates as opposed to sliding (only the Z axis slides)
5) I cannot think of a better design for making round objects
6) You can make the printer look like R2D2! :)

The main pitfalls of this design are:
1) X/Y resolution is variable, being lowest on the outer perimeter and highest in the center
2) High speed near the center can be difficult to achieve (special code could help)

** Construction

The dish is actuated by a pancake stepper that makes it rotate, to keep the height low, improving stability. I think the best way is to have a 200mm “Lazy Susan” bearing and a timing belt glued to the outside of the bearing (with the teeth outward), contacting the stepper directly, but a tensioned timing belt or nylon (printed) gear could also work well.

The “arm” can have a smaller diameter but making it as wide as can be printed should help make the design more stable. It can harbor a NEMA 17 stepper (or NEMA 23, even better) and the “hand” should best be sat on a 300mm linear slide bearing, such as HIWIN 12 which can be found reasonably cheap on and actuated by a NEMA 17 size stepper with a lead screw (again not expensive), standing in front of the said linear bearing.

If the filament is to be stored on the top it would be better if the supporting surface had a shaft connecting it to the base. This would make the filament not move around and cause problems, like unwinding and additional load/inertia.

Unlike the arm and the hand, the dish does not require end stop and can infinitely rotate. It can have a heater which would be connected via brushed contacts. Its temperature sensor would be stationary with a small bearing fitted over it (it would be the axis of the bearing) touching the bottom part of the plate. This would provide conductive heat transfer to the sensor while avoiding additional brushed terminals, needed if it were fixed to the plate.

And that is it, basically. There are some equations that provide the A and B angles from X and Y coordinates, considering radius r1 “dish” and r2 “arm”, but should be easy for a mathematician. I'm a bit rusty, any volunteers?

This printer would work better if code was optimized to take advantage of the circular motion. For example, filling would best be done in a circular motion /using circular pattern.

You are welcome to improve my design and actually design the printer parts. I have little time available at the moment, but will be glad to discuss and give suggestions.

So, I wonder, is there anyone out there brave enough to take on this cool project?

spool holder for XMachines Lorei printer. Attaches to the back of the printer using the two cover plate screws. Insert a piece of 1/2" PVC tubing cut to your desired length.

I added a taller version for holding larger spools that is also flush with the edge of the printer, and an end cap to keep the spools from riding off the end of the PVC.

The taller version is too flimsy for large spools. I made a new version (rev 6) that is designed to be used with some 1/2" PVC. Nice and sturdy and can hold two large spools without issue. I put a hole in the front for a screw to hold the PVC in place, but the fit was so tight, I didn't need it.

parts needed for rev 6:
1 - 5" x 1/2" PVC (cut one end at about a 30 degree angle to fit to the bottom of the base
2 - 4" x 1/2" PVC
1 - 1/2" TEE PVC
1 - printed rev 6 base
2 - printed end caps

Also, if you have the thinner spools (Hatchbox is about 2 1/4" wide), they shouldn't come close to the bed anyway.  I have some spools that are over 3" wide, so I needed the taller holder for more clearance.
